title: 104_hr392
content: The "Investment for America Act" reinstates a 10-percent domestic investment tax credit. The "Investment for America Act" reinstates a 10-percent domestic investment tax credit under sections 46 and 48 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Investment for America Act" reinstates a 10-percent domestic investment tax credit for new and used domestic section 38 properties placed in service by the taxpayer during the taxable year. The applicable percentage is determined under specific rules from section 46(c) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Investment for America Act" reinstates a 10-percent domestic investment tax credit for new and used domestic section 38 properties completed in the United States, with at least 60 percent of the basis attributable to value added within the United States. The "Investment for America Act" reinstates a 10-percent domestic investment tax credit for new and used domestic section 38 properties completed in the United States, with at least 60 percent of the basis attributable to value added within the United States. Section 38 property includes tangible personal property used in manufacturing, production, extraction, transportation, communication, energy, gas, water, or sewage services, and research facilities related to these activities. The "Investment for America Act" reinstates a 10-percent domestic investment tax credit for new and used domestic section 38 properties completed in the United States. This includes tangible personal property used in various industries and research facilities. The Act also covers facilities for bulk storage of commodities, elevators, escalators, agricultural structures, and storage facilities. The curr_chunk discusses the definition of a storage facility used in connection with the distribution of petroleum or any primary product of petroleum. It includes property eligible for depreciation with a useful life of 3 years or more. Coordination with other tax credits is also mentioned. The curr_chunk discusses technical amendments related to certain progress expenditure rules and the basis of new and used domestic section 38 property. These rules are similar to those in effect before the Revenue Reconciliation Act of 1990. The curr_chunk includes amendments to section 50(a) and section 48 of the Code related to special rules for certain domestic section 38 property. The curr_chunk introduces a new section 23 in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 regarding purchases of domestic durable goods. The effective date for the amendments made in this section is after December 31, 1994. The new section 23 in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows a 7% tax credit for individuals who purchase domestic durable goods. The credit is limited to $1,000 per taxable year and applies to goods completed in the United States with at least 60% of the basis attributable to value added within the country. The new section 23 in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows a 7% tax credit for individuals who purchase domestic durable goods, limited to $1,000 per taxable year. Section 24 provides a tax credit for certain costs incurred in purchasing an American-made passenger vehicle, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 1994. Tax credit allowed for qualified payments made by an individual for State or local sales tax on a qualified automobile and interest on a loan secured by the automobile. Qualified automobile must be domestically produced and purchased after December 31, 1994, with original use by the taxpayer. Tax credit allowed for qualified payments made by an individual for State or local sales tax on a qualified automobile and interest on a loan secured by the automobile. The automobile must be domestically produced, with more than 60 percent produced in the United States and final assembly in the United States. No double benefit allowed for payments eligible for this credit. Sec. 24 allows for certain costs incurred in purchasing an American-made passenger vehicle. The effective date for these amendments is for taxable years ending after December 31, 1994. Additionally, Section 5 discusses the placement of "Made in America" labels on products. Products must meet specific requirements to bear a "Made in America" label, including registration with the Department of Commerce, 60% of the product being manufactured in the US, and final assembly taking place in the US. A registry of American-made products must be maintained, and penalties exist for fraudulent use of such labels. The text suggests penalties for fraudulent use of "Made in America" labels, including a civil fine of up to $100,000 and the Secretary's authority to issue injunctions for non-compliance. The Secretary must establish registration procedures for products within 12 months of this Act's enactment. Definitions include "label" as any written or graphic matter on a product, and "Secretary" as the Secretary of Commerce.
